baseline_groups.claim_summary: The 1927 Mississippi flood caused a persistent decline in Black population share in affected Southern counties, consistent with flood-induced out-migration of Black workers.
baseline_groups.notes: Table 2 Column 1. DiD with county FE (absorbed), state-year FE + geographic controls + lagged outcomes as explicit regressors, clustered SE at county level, weighted by county area. Focal parameter is f_int_1930 (first post-flood decade). Additional baseline variants at f_int_1950 (row 019) also recorded.

baseline_groups.claim_summary: The 1927 Mississippi flood caused an increase in farm equipment value (mechanization) in affected Southern counties, consistent with labor scarcity inducing capital-labor substitution.
baseline_groups.notes: Table 4 Column 2. DiD with county FE (absorbed), state-year FE + geographic controls + lagged equipment values as explicit regressors, clustered SE at county level, weighted by county area. Focal parameter is f_int_1940 (peak mechanization response). Additional baseline variants at f_int_1930 (row 041, pre-trend) and f_int_1970 (row 042, long-run) also recorded.

global_notes: Surface defined two baseline groups matching the paper's two main claims: (G1) flood reduced Black population share, (G2) flood increased farm mechanization. No changes to baseline group assignments from the pre-run surface. 46 specifications were planned (23 per group). 36 succeeded and 10 failed due to matrix singularity, primarily in G2 where the sparser agricultural census panel creates collinearity issues. All successful G1 specs yield negative coefficients. All successful G2 specs with f_int_1940 focal yield positive coefficients. The G2 f_int_1930 pre-trend check is correctly null (p=0.796). Inference variants (HC1 robust and state-level clustering) all succeed and preserve significance for both groups.
